transcript.content: The Darkness - Growing on Me
Oh, proper rock band, best band since Thin Lizzy; The Darkness.
Oh, big words.
Growing On Me. XFM, 104.9.
That's a bit rash, I think.
Aa- uh, R. Gervais, S. Merchant, K. Pilkington. With a little bit of- ah, I know your- I know for a fact, uh, that Steve is getting a little bit sick of Karl's attitude.
Oh, his attitude's appalling!
Ricky laughs
I quite like it though because it-
Straightaway friction and he's sort of like, you know.
To be fair, I genuinely don't think I'm the culprit in this. I think I come in and I just ask him a simple request.
Yeah.
And immediately on my back. Whinging, moaning, whining. Ah- I do- I mean, I don't know if there's any evidence... to sort of...
Well it's funny you should say that actually, because uhh...
Support any of my complaints.

In a survey. Yeah, it came up this, this week. It's, uh, quite extensive. Um, Mancunians take more six day- sick days than anyone else. Mancunians take more sick days than workers in any other city in Britain and Ireland.

According to Manchester-based employment firm. Survey, uhhh, by Peninsula found, uh, employees in Manchester take 11 six day- d- sick days per year, whereas closest rivals Edinburgh and Dublin, um, take an average of nine. Liverpool, Newcastle, Birmingham, Cardiff, only eight.
Is Reading mentioned there, or Bristol?
No, it's not even in th-, it's not even in there.
Sure.

They don't take, days off. Umm, London is only- only seven. So- so the point is, I mean, d- I don't think you can take anything from it, but, if you're an employer and you had a Mancunian and a Liverpudlian and they were equal on everything else.
But you really couldn't afford them to be away, Liverpudlian's gonna probably be away for, eight days.
Sure.
Mm.
The Manc's gonna be away for eleven, phoning in sick and i-
So what can you, I mean, just-
Well it's, the point is it's-
Analysing the data there, how can- what would you extrapolate from that?
Um, I d- I, I really don't know. I mean, call in if you've got any clues, or email us in if you've got any... I don't know why they- I- I think maybe... I dunno. Mancunians, just...
I mean I don't really know many people from Manchester.
Well I only know one, but I know he was off sick because he put on wet trousers and he got a-
He got a cold, I think.
Yeah, well he just said he was...
Yeah.
Didn't come in for...
Um, he left early as well once.
Yeah, yeah.
Um, but, uhh, but I don't know. B- that's the survey, I dunno. I mean it's evidence because it's statistics so... there you go.
It's guaranteed evidence, that that's actually proof.
So, any... any thoughts on that: ricky.gervais@xfm.co.uk.
Ma- I mean you're from, oddly enough you're from Manchester, Karl-
Yeah I am, yeah yeah yeah, that's funny yeah.
What are your thoughts on, on that.
On what, sorry?
Dyoo! On the survey!
Ahh, wasn't really listening.
Sure.
Wh- Manc-Mancunians take off more sick days. They call in sick,
I mean purs- presumably spuriously.
Yeah.
I mean, 'cause it's, it's d- they've got the same body, they're...
Exactly.
...biologically the same, so, or-or
So they're obviously making it up, they're lying, they're whinging.
Yeah, some of- some of the days, maybe they're just the- the three extra they're making up.
Yeah, they're moaning.
Um...
Probably 'cause we work a lot harder than the others, so we're tired, so you're sick, so you need time off. Probably, probably.
Well...
Seems unlikely.
I mean the Scousers, to be honest, yeah, take 'em on, let 'em work in your office. But, you know, how many computers are gonna go missing?
Right, that...
So offensive.
Is offensive-
Right.
This is a- this is a- no! This is a survey that proved, you just made that up. You just carried on the myth that Liverpudlians
Thieve.
Mm.
Now that- that is just, that's not true. That is not true.
Well.
Well it's not!
Well, some of 'em do.
There's- there's been no survey that you're more likely to thieve if you're from Liverpool than if you're from Manchester, so that- that hasn't been proven yet.
Mm. Mm.
So all- all I've got is the evidence, from a survey, of I think three and a half thousand people.
Well.
It's proof that people f- Mancunians take off more sick days. XFM 104.9, this is April Come She Will by Simon & Garfunkel.
Simon & Garfunkel - April Come She Will

Simon & Garfunkel, April Come She Will. A lovely, lovely love song there. Uhh, The X-List was all about, sort of like, sexy songs, cause of, uh, death of- uh, Barry White of course. And uh, Karl and Steve having a little argument, Steve saying there are- are such thing as sexy songs of course. Karl says "I can't understand it."
No.

"I can't understand it, how can summat be sexy? How can you woo a woman with a song?" Steve went, "Well, you don't woo 'em with it, you just put it on in the background." Karl said, "Stick the telly on."
"Stick the telly on."
I love that.
You don't believe there's any such thing as a sexy song, is that right?
I- I- I don't think it can get you in the mood, d'you know what I mean?
Right.
Ricky chuckles
You- You're either in with a chance or you're not, I don't think it matters what- what song you put on.
Well- I d- I don't think it ups your chances. I don't think if you take-
No it does, it does. If you- if you put Channel 5 on on a Friday night, right? See a little bit of that action, gets anyone going.
Steve laughs
It's worked for me, and that's all- and that's what I'm saying.
What's on? Whe- 'When Pets Go Mad'?
No no no, you know like, uhh-
What?
I don't know the titles of them,
I don't look at the titles, but-
What, that show with Chris Moyles?
Eh.
Do you mean the kind of, erotic thrillers that they have on?
Yeah yeah, put- put one of them on, that's, that gets you going a bit.
Steve laughs
Wha- wha does, what does she-
I might be tired, and that, but...
What d-, what d-, wh- wha-, does the- w- is-, What does the woman go, go "Oh, that's an idea. 'ey that's an idea!"
But don't- normally they're, they're normally called something like 'Illegal Briefs'...
Ricky laughs
And they're normally about, you know, they're normally about some kind of, uh, female solicitor who's defending a guy who may or may not be a li- uhh, a killer.
Yeah.
But maybe in a former life they were lovers, it's always some nonsense like that. And presumably, there's normally
Some gruesome murders, so how's that getting you in the mood?
It's plot development.
Yeah, it's the narrative, oh, I love narrative.
Yeah. "I'll tell you what, that's a lovely twist, I've got the 'orn."
Steve laughs
Yeah.

Brilliant. So, uh, if you're from Manchester, sorry about that. I mean, it is true, we aren't- weren't making that up, we weren't doing a st- a stupid stereotype like Karl did with Liverpudlians it's, it's just a survey that, Mancunians take off more sick days. And uh- eh- but that might be genuine, they might be sort of an iller- iller people, or... it might just be people who are in- in Manchester go "Oh, I can't be bothered to go to
Work it's rubbish. Whereas if you're in London you go "Oh, I can't wait to go to work-
Exactly... yeah.
"What a lovely, what a lovely place this is and-"
There's some great jobs down here.
Great jobs down here.
Yeah.
Ummmm-
Uh, Rick, I know you're always looking, uh, just to- keep you- kept abreast of, you know, new developments-
Yeah.
-of music, what's happening.
Yeah.
I don't know if you got any plans this evening, but you might want to pop along to The Hope & Anchor in Islington.
Why?
Where, uhh, playing tonight, umm, 'Restless Diesel'.
"Please welcome to the stage..."
'Restless Diesel'. I mean we've talked about it before, band names where you just have to imagine, you're supporting U2-
Yeah.
Wembley Stadium, it can never happen!
Please welcome to the stage 'Restless diesel'.
And he comes on and after the first song he goes, uh, "Thanks, cuz, great band before us, Restless Diesel, you'll hear a lot more of them."
Exactly. So uh...
Yeah. It- it won't happen, will it?
Sure they're a great band, I think they should change their name.
What's the tax on that? Fiver, then, is it?
Steve laughs
It's not, uhh, not telling us actually, but uh yeah, d- pop down to the Hope & Anchor, maybe tell us, uh, how Restless Diesel were tonight.
Yeah, just uh, call in maybe, uhh, call in on, uh, Christian's show, Monday, just tell us how Restless Diesel were. We can make that a regular feature. Uhhhh-
Now what's coming up on today's show, what've we got?
Well listen, we've got all the usual favourites. We got, uh- and some new ones, we got Monkey News. That's sorted. Karl told me-
People are guaranteed Monkey News.
He called in, he said "I've got some Monkey News."
Brilliant.
He's done that, I had to make sure, yeah we've got that. We've got, um, some great tunes. I've got a great song from Tupac, some Cat Stevens, some Jimmy Webb, some Thin Lizzy.
Can I surprise you with something from Aerosmith.
Brilliant.
A little treat from Evan Dando coming up.
We- we're quite rocky today, aren't we? Uhh, there's, there's a threat there won't be Rockbusters.
Good.
Uhh-
Ricky chuckles
That's no threat.
Ricky laughs
But um,
Great news.
We can bring back Educating Ricky.

I mean 'cos it's sorta like seasonal, isn't it? our show. You don't know what, it's not like Ant and Dec's takeaway is on all through the year. They go away for a few weeks and we get summat else like Ian Wrights, you know, friends like these or summat you know. And so maybe Rockbusters maybe not.
Rockbusters is on Hiatus but educating Ricky always - if you've not heard that before
I'll tell you what Jane's Addiction just because they rock as well don't they? XFM 104.9.
Ohhh Excellent.
Jane's Addiction just because on Xfm 104.9 broadcasting from London where people prefer to only be off sick. When they actually are ill, you know?
I don't have ever taken a day off sick except well, I that terrible, terrible, terrible tonsillitis.
Is that when you went home, stayed with your mom and dad?
Why's that a problem? Nursed back to health - got a loving family so sue me.
I love it the antagonism and piss taking its just like ahh god three blokes in a pub - there's people listening
Are there? Umm Karl what do you make of London because you often say you'd much rather be up north
Well he wouldn't or he'd go
Well this is what I - he constantly says
You've chosen to live here, you've lived here for years, you got a flat here
No, I chose to come here because I was offered a job that was good money
Yeah
I wouldn't have come here if there was no job
So you prefer to be somewhere where there's a good job
I don't like being here though
Well no but you can leave
To what?
Well EXACTLY so you've chosen to stay somewhere that's better for you
It's not better for me, its making me ill. I'm not sleeping
Well you say you're ill, you call in ill but I don't think you are
Are there any stats to prove that?
Well yeah because of the 11 days he calls in sick, I reckon probably 7 of them are genuine
Ahh i'd love it if I dropped down dead tonight - honestly i'd love it
If you dropped down dead tonight, you'd love it?
Yeah
Why aren't you sleeping?
What you're feeling ill now are ya? That's funny you weren't feeling ill earlier but you read that and you're suddenly ill
I'm run down
Well you should take a holiday. Oh yeah you've just had about eight in the last six months
HAHAHA ohh god
Why are you run down?
Yeah what have you done, you sit in a little air conditioned office

I haven't got time to tell ya, let's move on, let's get on with stuff what have we got anyway cos we uhh we didn't have a chance to meet up this week - me and Ricky could've done but you said you were busy Steve soo that's probably why you don't get run down finishing work at about 4 o'clock
No no I could have had the meeting but uh we gave you a time and you suddenly decided with very little notice that you couldn't make it so uh
Meetings an that - so what've we got then what've we got its 20 past one what've we got we're on til three

Well we've been talking we've been doin well, we've been playing some great rock n' roll we've been playing some lovely songs we've told em, we've explained the survey just for employees be careful we've put that out there we've put a shout out there
I mean would you say it was probably safest if you are an employer to never employ mancunians?

Well I wouldn't go that far because you see thats only an average so I imagine some Mancunians like you know Londoners you know are nice, reliable people it's probably only a few bad eggs that throw the stats up a little bit, you know people that would go "I'm not coming in today I put up some wet trousers" "oh alright, stay in bed stay in bed, you still got em on?" "yeah" "well pop em off, put em on the radiator and go to bed"
There with a little duvet, that'd be the best thing to do.
Yeah. Yeah.
So uh, all right, Karl?
Alright.
Alright, what's your attitude? Is it cause you're tired?
Yeah.
But why are you tired though?
You weren't staying up watching those Channel 5 films again, were you?
Ricky snorts.

I'll tell you what, we were, me and Steve, were having a little meeting yesterday over lunch about, you know, planning stuff for the show and uh, Gary Kemp came up to me. Started having a little chat about old times and uh, I went "Oh yeah". As he went away Steve said, right think of this, he said

Rick, don't take this the wrong way. Remember that sentence "don't take this the wrong way". So there's a right way and a wrong way I could've taken this comment. He went, nodded to sort of Gary Kemp and when "he's aged better than you". I went, "Well, how could I take that the wrong way?"
Yeah. It's not offensive.
No. Well the p-point is this, he- he does possess- he didn't know me, 20 years ago, so he's actually saying: "Rick, don't take this the wrong way. He looks better than you do".
Yeah. Well he does.
But why say that Karl?
What?
Did you really say that?
Yeah, although can I just- just backtracking for a second, I love the fact you said, we bumped into Gary Kemp and you reminisced about old times. What old times did you share with Gary Kemp?

Well, no he came up and said, "did we do Top of the Pops together?" and I went: "No I only did Razzmatazz. He said: " Oh we did Razzmatazz". I think he was thinking had he ever met me before. But he- he hadn't because we hadn't. That's what I meant.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Mm.
And uh--
But if you had to make an objective analysis, you know--
I- I wouldn't. I think that's out of order.
Sure, sure.
Ricky holds back laughter.
I mean, you're always slagging me off but apparently you can't value judgment on something else.
Steve and Karl talk over one another incoherently.
No no no. I wouldn't- I wouldn't- I wouldn't do that.
Ricky snorts.
Because you're, you know, you're morally all over the place, you know? You don't know whether you're coming or going.
Leave it.
Yeah.
Leave it.
Yeah.
You should hear what I say about you behind your back.
So are you- would you say you're better looking now than you were, or?
Ricky snickers.
(Incoherent)
Wou- would you say you're better looking now than you were?
Than I was when?
Well like- like you know, have you aged well?
Yes.
Ricky continues to snicker.
You've aged well?
Yeah, I've kept my looks.
Oh.
Ricky begins to laugh more.
Bit of Dando?
Bit of Evan Dando, this'll be lovely yeah.
Ricky snickers again.

transcript.content: Evan Dando - Looking for Space
Radiohead - Go to Sleep
Radiohead, Go to sleep.
That's good innit? On Xfm 104.9.
Steve chuckles.
Brilliant. Great DJing there.
Well I haven't heard it before.
Good innit.
Yeah.

Well it was good. It was very good. It was very good. Uhm, I was just watching uh- cable TV. I do a lot of that, and uhm, there's an advert I've noticed. It reminded me of uhm, the sort of adverts I used to see when I was a kid. It's one of those attempts to kind of educate young people, but doing it in--
(incoherent)
Yeah.
Yeah.
It's- it's on MTV, but it's one of those things where it's clearly been made by people who are in their mid 40s.
Who've never been cool.
Who've never been cool.
Yeah.
Who've been working really hard to get into TV, all their lives.
Yeah.
And uh, and now are trying to appeal to you know funky and possibly wayward young people.
Yeah.
And it's kind of--
Ne'er-do-wells.
Yes. Exactly. And it's uh, it's the kind of uh stunning model and two of her stunning model friends. But they're just a couple of average girls, you know--
Sure.

Going about their business. And, you know, it says something like uhm- and it's all shot very funky like a kind of, you know, Lock Stock and Two Smoking Barrels, kinda thing. And uh there's this girl and she's just grooving along with her friends and it's kind of like, the- the captions are things like, you know, Isabella 17--

She's cool, she's quite funky, she's got these great friends, and they're sort of hanging out laughing, and she just pops in to a tattoo parlour, why not? Her friends are like 'what are you doing ?!?'.

But she just goes in, y'know, she has a tattoo done, and it sort of says 'she's wild! she's crazy!' y'know, 'she lives life as she sees it! She takes every day as it comes! She's not tied down to anything' bla bla bla 'she doesn't smoke cigarettes.'
Yeah ...
If you think she's cool ...
If you think all this is cool, then, then you probably won't want to smoke cigarettes.
Exactly, yeah.
If you wanna be cool ...
Like Isabella or whatever her name is ...
Except the thing with that is that people watching that, 'the youth' watching that will go 'well Bill at my school, he smokes and he's cool'.
Exactly.
Yeah.
This is the problem with it.
Yeah.
It's not that the impulse is wrong, the message is fine, it's just this thing, I don't, I can't imagine those things ever working with young people.
It's like, when you see, what was it ... rock ...
What it will do is that you'll get a lot of thirteen and fourteen year olds sneaking out and getting a tattoo. So the parents will be going 'I'D RATHER SHE SMOKED!!'.
Exactly, she might give that up!
'She's got a spider's web on her face now for the rest of her life!'
Exactly!
But it's sort of like, remember that thing when they tried to get young people to vote, do you remember that, was it 'Rock the Vote'?
Ohhhhhhh god.
Was it people like Billy Bragg and people, kind of ...
I just, I don't know who that appeals to, I don't know, y'know, if some youth is kinda smashing up a bus shelter, throwing bricks at old people.
What's that? Billy Bragg?
Billy Bragg, yeah ...
I just can't, I don't believe it ever ... I think it was Mick Hucknall was another one.
Ricky laughs.
What's that Mick?
Ohhhhhh dear.
I remember the ones where if you, err, if you were gonna go off with a stranger, your cat went 'well, dont'.
'Ask mummy first'.
Yeah.
I remember I was trying to jump in cars left right and center, but my cat, when I was about five or six would go ...
Ricky imitates the sound of Charley from the 'Charley Says' cartoon.
And I'd go 'good point, you're right, he could be a nutter'.
But I seem to remember the 'Charley Says' ... it was 'Charley Says' wasn't it?
'Charrlllleeeyyyy Sayssssss!'
I always found them really unnerving, he lived in that really eerie kind of world where you kind of never really saw ...
What, a cartoon?
Yeah but it was very eerie, it wasn't very, kind of, comforting world ...
Yeah, they hadn't spend a lot of money on the cartoon.
I always got the sense with him that he was probably really quite lonely.
I like the fact that ...
And he had a cat that talked ...

'Mummy was so pleased, that by the time I'd come back they'd gone off and I'd missed the picnic, but mummy was so pleased that I'd asked her she gave me an apple'. And Charley got something that he liked, he gets a fish, right ...
I was thinking ... 'an apple?!?'
Now I seem to remember it being ...
'I get an apple anyway, get me some sweets!'
Yeah, or a tattoo.
I always thought that it was a con when your parents got you, erm, some clothes you needed for Christmas.
Yeah.
I'm not falling for that ... I'd go 'look, I'm getting the clothes anyway. I want Battling Tops'.

But the 'Charley Says' I seem to remember when they asked him to go off for the picnic, by the time he'd asked mum because she was on the phone, I don't know who she was chatting to in the middle of the day.
Yeah ...
Steve chuckles.
The kids had gone ...
One of her clients.
Steve laughs.
Exactly.
Ricky laughs.
I seem to remember that he said that 'don't worry, it was fine because mum took him and Charley on a picnic'.
Not as good.
Who would rather go ... with your mates ...
Yeah.
Or with your mum ...
... and your cat.
I mean ... I think ...
Ohhhh mum! This scotch egg stinks of fish!
Well, I had to bring it for Charlie. Don't bring raw fish in the picnic basket.
What I think is those- they weren't friends of his, they were just local kids who'd go 'Let's go and- let's go and ask that weirdo with the cat if he wants to come down the park.
Ricky laughs.
Let's go and ask the weirdo who thinks the cat can talk--
He can talk, yeah.
And then run away when he goes to ask his mum.
When he goes off to ask his mum they're just going (imitates chicken)
Yeah. Yeah.
'Oh ask your mum, ask your mum'.
Yeah. Yeah. 'Hello.', 'Hiya.',  'Alright, we're the local lads, the cool local lads. We smoke. We got tattoos. Um, do you want to come and play with some puppies in the disused mine?'
'Um, sh- ask your mum first. Quick. Run.
Yeah. Exactly.
'He's talking to the cat. Look he's talking to the cat'.
They were just around the corner, spying on him.
Ricky laughs.
Yeah.
They were just laughing. There was no picnic.
Did you ever go on a picnic Karl? It was- was there places to go in Manchester? or was it like 'Quarryland' mostly?.
Yeah, yeah, yeah. The problem with those uh- those adverts- like when I was growing up, it'd sort of give you ideas because remember the Charlie's one, right?
Yeah.
And we were on holiday, right? And I met these two lads who I was knocking about with. Like mates and that.
And that advert came on and we thought it'd be a good idea to wind his Mam up. Because this advert had just been on saying, you know, kids are going missing in Wales, right?
Yeah.
So I said oh this'll be a good laugh. We put the kid in the wardrobe. His Mam came back from shopping. We said, oh, he's gone missing we haven't seen him for hours.
That's terrifying.
I know.
That's appalling.
How old were you?
About 13.
And what was his mum- she must've been- she must've been in a frenzy.
She was- she was- yeah. Yeah, she was going mad and that's when we thought 'Oh God, we've- we've gone- will we say anything? Will we pretend we don't know where he is?'
Open the wardrobe, he'd suffocated.
Yeah.
That's horrible, Karl.
I know, but it's just what you do innit. It's just what you do.
Steve talks over Karl incoherently.
Well, no. You do.
What do you mean? It's just what you do. What was- was he in the wardrobe? Was he listening to this? Why didn't he go 'Mum, It's all right', when he heard her crying?
She weren't crying, she was just panicking and like--
Yeah.
Screaming a little bit and that.
'And screaming a little bit'
Ricky laughs.
Okay, we'll tell her when the screaming starts.
Exactly. Yeah.
And then uh- what's the other thing? Like on the same- like you know, the- all this was going on when I was growing up and um, one time we were on holiday-
And me Mam said 'Right. If you're going on the beach, it's a big beach um, but, you know, if you're going to go out and play there, I need to know where you are'.
So wear these bells.
Ricky laughs.
Or at least wear this cowbell--
It's a lead.
She gave me a balloon.
Good idea.
She gave you a balloon?
A balloon. And it just uh, you know, sort of attached to me arm. So wherever I was playing in the sea and that, you can see the balloon and that.
Brilliant.
Uh. But, then the problem was, everyone else though that was a good idea.
Go on.
And there was just like loads of kids with balloons and that.
Oh, they've ruined it.
So that- that didn't work.
Yeah.
Had to bin that.
Sure.
Bin that idea.
Well did- didn't- weren't you in a car park once?

Oh no. I- it was New Year and uh, it- we were all gathering up. You know like in Trafalgar Square at New Year everyone gathers and they have a big kind of party and stuff. Well in Bristol they do something very similar on a smaller scale and I was there one New Year. I was with my friends. And uh- I was- I for some reason I picked up a balloon during the evening, you know, I don't know where I got it from but I was holding this balloon and these girls came up to me and I thought, Ah. Nice. Nice, you know, maybe a little New Year kiss. They come up, they said uh, 'Hey'.
'Are you going to be here for a- for a while?' And I said 'Well, yeah. You know, I probably will.' They said 'It's just that we've arranged to meet back at you. At midnight'.
Ricky laughs.
Cause you're so tall.

I was- what do you mean? Cause I was so tall and I had a balloon? I was towering above everyone else. They said- I said- I said- I said 'What?'. They said 'We're going to meet back at you at midnight'.
Ricky laughs.
This- this is--
They said 'Don't worry. You can go about your business because we can see you wherever you are'.
This is where Nelson's Column is?
Ricky laughs.
No, no, no. No, this is in Bristol.
All right. Okay.
Yeah. Yeah. And um- and so uh--

So I'm sort of wandering around and then at midnight they- they- th- th- th- these two girls turned up again and some of their- these lads come and meet them. And uh they're sort of laughing and joking. I'm thinking 'oh they're probably gonna invite me back to a party'. I watched them get in a cab. They went off. They had a wild night. But then I did have a balloon, so it's a great year for me.
Ricky laughs.
I did have a ballon. Oh, should we little bit of uh, bit of Tupac?
Uh, yeah if you want yeah.
Yeah?
Put a bit of that on.
There's a great lyric in this. It's- It's uh Picture Me Rollin', right?
Mhm.
But at the end he starts sort of saying about um--

Uh 'Look at me now. I've got, I'm y'know, drinking Remy and I'm in a Rolls-Royce' and he goes, "oh yeah I forgot! The D.A. Can she see me from here? Can you see me, ho?'. And I think of this like district attorney turning on the radio and Tupac running around going "Can that ho see me?". She's going, 'Yeah, yeah I could see you'.
Yeah.
It's brilliant.
Tupac - Picture Me Rollin'
Tupac.
I tell you what we should get rolling.
Steve chuckles.
Rockbusters.
No.
Alright.
No.
Well he has done it, he just said that he was worried about it because we said it's the last one. What do you think, Karl?
I just don't think we- I mean can I just say now, oh Karl seriously I'm only responding to what we're getting on the email, which is people do not want Rockbusters.
Alright. Alright.
